author: anagram1964
content: Question, if we want to stake ETH as a validator is there a way to hedge using DeFi so we don't lose if the price of ETH collapses? The main issue with ETH 2 staking compared to Tezos for example is excessive risk which could result in centralization around exchanges.

author: anagram1964
content: Any exchange could offer some sort of token which hedges against the price of ETH falling but it's a big gamble for people to stake in a token which has no price floor. It's not like bonds, or dividend stocks.

author: _0xuser
content:
> Any exchange could offer some sort of token which hedges against the price of ETH falling but it's a big gamble for people to stake in a token which has no price floor. It's not like bonds, or dividend stocks.
<@255131692090523665> Some staking pools/providers/... may tokenize the staking, so you will be able to trade it on ETH 1. I know that for example Rocket Pool will do that with rETH, and it's decentralized.

author: cryptograthor
content: <@!413635991233101825> Oh interesting. Tokenize as in, here's an NFT representing ownership of some staked Eth? If I'm understanding that right, a byzantine validator could do some sneaky stuff and then sell the tokenized Eth.

author: _0xuser
content:
<@182312175304441856> depending if you are running a node (with a deposit of 16 ETH) or delegating your ETH to a node (to cover the remaining 16 ETH) you get nETH or rETH (ERC20s)
nETH only becomes available to the node operator when he stops validating. So he has liquidity of his past staking until phase0. This avoids the risk of lack of incentives to behave properly.
rETH is for delegator and become available as soon as they deposit their ETH.

In case of penalization with validator below 16 ETH, rETH holders recover their 16 ETH and the node operator loses his 16 ETH deposit

author: anagram1964
content:
> <@!255131692090523665> Some staking pools/providers/... may tokenize the staking, so you will be able to trade it on ETH 1. I know that for example Rocket Pool will do that with rETH, and it's decentralized.
<@!413635991233101825> I know this will not be a popular question but someone has to ask it. What are the tax implications? If I transfer ETH 1 to get ETH 2 to stake, is it going to be a tax event by US IRS standards? Will I then owe potentially many thousands or perhaps even millions of dollars in taxes? I think there is a lot of risk here which using technical means can be mitigated. The loss of liquidity is just the opportunity cost problem but that can be solved the easiest. What about tax efficiency and protecting stakers against big losses? Miners for example would not mine if they all know they could lose all their investment if the price collapses but with mining you can mine some other token.

author: anagram1964
content: With ETH once you stake ETH 2.0 there is no way out. You're stuck in that decision.

author: jgm
content: You don't swap ETH1 for ETH2, you transfer your Ether from the Ethereum 1 network to the Ethereum 2 network.  Same token.

author: anagram1964
content: But the IRS seems to say that like kind does not exist, and who knows how this will be treated. Is anyone here an expert on these matters? I agree it's the same token, but the IRS is not rational.

author: edson.eth
content: I don't think so. It's an upgrade to the same platform. Ethereum 2 isn't a new entity

author: edson.eth
content: And, even in the case of mergers, where new stock replaces the old stock, it's not seen as a taxable event https://finance.zacks.com/tax-stocks-exchanged-through-merger-acquisition-11818.html

author: edson.eth
content: But, worst case, one taxable event wouldn't be the end of the world. It's unlikely imo. If it were to happen, it'd show the irs really doesn't understand cryptocurrency, and someone else should be setting those kinds of rules
